newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland, May 23.

text.p: of stories from the Irish press on Friday.
- Ireland's Labour Party has a week to save the "Rainbow Coalition" from election defeat. Unless its support moves several points higher, its drop in seats will offset any gains
by Fine Gael, the biggest party in government.
- Sinn Fein was the major benefactor from a rise in the nationalist vote in Northern Ireland's local council elections, leaving unionists in danger of losing control of Belfast city council.
- Economists fear the troubles of the Irish pound could wipe out the potential gains from membership of the single European currency.
- The full costs of the 250-million-punt gas interconnector linking supplies in Ireland with the UK were not properly considered, the state's public spending watchdog concluded.
- Institutional investors are switching their equity
investments in the Irish stock market to reflect the recent currency changes which, if maintained, will provide a major boost to Irish companies with U.S. and UK interests.
- The Smurfit Group has decided to sell its

loss-making Irish timber processing subsidiary, Woodfab. - James Crean Plc is close to the conclusion of a deal which will involve a 32.7-million-punt payout for shareholders of its redeemable convertible loan stock.

- The Progressive Democrats have created the most explosive election issue so far by targeting single mothers. - Talks are continuing at a high level between the financial representatives of Avonmore Foods and Waterford Foods in an effort to find a basis for a merger of the two operations. - The Irish economy risks an inflationary overdose through a cocktail of exchange rate, interest rate and budgetary stimulus in the year ahead, a leading economist has warned.

IRISH TIMES - Irish Times/MRBI poll finds Irish government parties most trusted to create jobs. - Main Unionist parties could lose hold on three councils in Northern Ireland. - The slide of the Irish pound on currency markets has been halted as speculators took some profits after the heavy selling a day earlier. - AIB shares jumped five pence to a record high of 503 pence after it became the first Irish bank to get an Aa3 financial strength rating from credit rating agency Moody's Investors Service. - JS Corp sets up strategic review of its operations. - Ireland's hopes of joining the EU have increased according to investment bank JP Morgan.
